moves.1. e4 e5 2. f4 exf4 3. Bc4 Qh4+ 4. Kf1: White invites this check, producing complications.
moves.4... Bc5 5. d4 Bb6 6. Nf3: Black's attempts for an early checkmate thwarted, now white begins the counterattack.
moves.6... Qf6 7. e5: Whte decides to exploit an edge in development and space
moves.7... Qf5 8. Nc3 c6 9. Bd3 Qg4 10. Ne4: White has provoked Black into allowing a strong N outpost while Black's queen is vulnerable to being pushed around with tempo.
moves.10... Bc7 11. h3 Qe6 12. Bxf4: White wins back the pawn and maintains a space and tempo advantage.
moves.12... d5: Black decides to sacrifice a pawn to try and get some freedom, but also offers opening for White to exploint the advantage in space and development.
moves.13. exd6 e.p. Bd8 14. Kf2: Now Black has to worry about a rook on the e-file and pins against the king.
moves.15. Neg5: The start of a plan to exploit the king position before Black can castle.
moves.15... Qd5: Black apparently hopes to interpose with B-e6, but makes yet another Queen move with limited retreat squares.
moves.16. Re1+ Be6 17. c4: Black now has only one square left for the Queen.
moves.17... Qa5 18. Nxe6 fxe6 19. Rxe6+ Kf7: Apparently trying to provoke the check.
moves.20. Ng5+ Kf8 21. c5: Threatens to trap the Queen and to open up the c4 diagonal for attacks.
moves.21... Nd5 22. Bd2: Suddenly, White either loses the trapped queen or is checkmated. After 22...Nb4 trying to save the Queen with a threat of NXB , White simply forces checkmate after 23 Qf3 ! B-f6 24 RxB ! Ke8 (forced) 25 Qe4  etc. Otherwise, the wandering Queen has run out of places to run and has nowhere to go.
